Tesla Motors' new sales and service center in the Red Hook neighborhood of Brooklyn, New York, is opening this Friday to the public. Customers will be able to custom-build, purchase, and take delivery of their Teslas at the location, and have them serviced there as well. Passersby can also just pop in to drool over the cars. This week Tesla invited Business Insider to take a tour of its new space. 
This was a look at a part of the service center. "We'll be able to service thousands of vehicles out of this location," Jeremy Snyder, the general manager for Tesla Motors northeast region told Business Insider. "Most people are used to dropping off their cars at a service center, where there's a tech assigned to a car and the car is sitting for like, a day, maybe two depending on what work you're waiting for, and they work on the car until it's completed. "Tesla takes a very different approach to service. What we do is much more of a pit-crew-style servicing of a car. If it's a small thing that needs work, we'll fast-lane it in, bring it out, within minutes or hours rather than days. If it's a bigger issue, there will be multiple people who get on that car immediately as it arrives." #tesla #automobiles #cars #brooklyn #newyork #servicecenter #motor #service #showroom #üöó

If you have a chalet for the odd ski trip or a seaside villa to summer in, 3rd Home might be for you. 
Unlike Airbnb and its peers, 3rd Home requires that you have a high end property in order to stay at other member properties. "3rd Home is a private club for luxury second homeowners," explains 3rd Home chief marketing officer Steve Zacks. "They are a like-minded group of wealthy individuals who have high standards of quality. Members open up their luxury homes to others in the club, without concern since they know they also have a home in the club." The properties cost anywhere from $495 to $995 a week, in addition to credits (called Keys) accrued when you pledge to let other members stay at your place. The Villas at Tribu in the Grenadines (pictured above) is located on an island with just 300 people so you can escape the hustle and bustle for a little while. For a deeper look at these luxury pads visit BusinessInsider.com/tech.

This recreation (right) of a famous and controversial photo (original left) is depicted in the Stephen King, Bridget Carpenter and J.J. Abrams Hulu original series, ‚Äú11.22.63‚Äù. The photo in question, dubbed the "backyard photo" of Lee Harvey Oswald, captures the enigmatic man holding the same type of rifle used to assassinate John F. Kennedy in one hand and two Communist newspapers in the other. In 1964, the photo went public on the cover of Life magazine and on the front page of the Detroit Free Press. Many believed the image to be fake. Oswald also claimed it was set-up. 
The photo was deemed authentic by the Warren Commission and a congressional committee, yet skeptics still believed it could be forged. Last year, however, Dartmouth College used sophisticated 3D imaging technology to study the photo and it, too, ruled that the photo is real. For more on the ‚Äú11.22.63‚Äù series and how they recreated everything from the set to bystander footage, visit BusinessInisder.com/entertainment.

See if you can spot the 'human chameleon' ‚Äî he's found a way to make himself practically invisible

Chinese artist Liu Bolin has an amazing talent. He can blend into any surroundings he chooses, making himself, or his subjects, practically undetectable to the human eye. Bolin, known to many as the "Human Chameleon", decorates the body and clothes with color, painting himself and his subjects into the surroundings, making them almost imperceptible at first glance. This mountain was once considered impossible to climb ‚Äî but this climber managed to do it, and the photos are breathtaking. 
Free climbing can be extremely dangerous. One of the most notoriously difficult routes for both free and rock climbing is The Nose at El Capitan in Yosemite, California. 
There are two main faces of El Capitan: the Southwest and the Southeast. The Nose lies between the two and is the most popular climb of El Cap. The 3,000-foot mountain was once considered impossible to climb due to the technicalities involved. 
The very first successful rock-climbing ascent of The Nose wasn't until 1958, and until 1993, no one had successfully free climbed it. Since then, only four people have successfully completed a free-climb ascent of The Nose. We got a chance to speak with one of those climbers, Jorg Verhoeven, and his photographer, Jon Glassberg, about the climb. 
See more: uk.businessinsider.com

At almost double the size of the world's current tallest building, Dubai's Burj Khalifa, the skyscraper would be the world's new tallest if built. Ma is a true rags-to-riches story. The mines in the northern part of the Brazilian state of Minas Gerais were once the most important diamond sources in the world. But the mines are long abandoned, now just craters stripped nearly bare by multinational mining companies. Yet in this rural and remote area, there are still hundreds of Brazilians who depend on the mines for survival. Without electricity, running water, or a steady income, these workers barely manage to survive ‚Äì unless their luck suddenly turns and a rare windfall springs forth. 
A find of this size could take months of strenuous work, but even untold months are no promise of success in this unforgiving environment. AP photographer Felipe Dana (@felipedana) recently traveled to the desolate and grueling mines of Areinha to document the struggling miners' experience. See it all at BusinessInsider.com

La Rinconada is the highest human habitation in the world and is home to some of the most brutal living conditions known to man. It's also an unregulated goldmine.

At a height of over 16,000 ft, it‚Äôs a place where only the hardest-skinned can carve a living. More than 50,000 people live in the settlement, perched atop Mount Ananea in the Peruvian Andes.

Despite its spectacular views, tourists avoid the town, which has no hotels or hospitals, and the government has little, almost no presence. Its economy relies almost entirely upon the surrounding unregulated gold mines, where miners work tirelessly to scrape together a living and often suffer from mercury poisoning and other illnesses as a result.

The town has no sanitation system and no running water, and spends much of the year in sub-zero temperatures

This is the 'doomsday' seed vault, where billions of seeds are stored in case of nuclear war.

Eight-hundred miles from the North Pole, on the remote island of Spitsbergen, a huge vault sits 130 metres inside a cavernous sandstone mountain.

Behind the thick concrete wall lies the most diverse selection of food crop seeds in the world. Seeds from almost every country line the shelves as an emergency food supply to be used only in the event of nuclear fallout, mass famine, or other global crises. The vault cost approximately $9 million to construct and was funded entirely by the Norwegian government as a service to the global community.

The first withdrawal from the "doomsday" vault was made this year in a bid to restore ancient crops wiped out by the Syrian civil war.

NASA just released close-up photos of the cataclysmic Antares rocket explosion, and they're eerily beautiful.

On Oct. 28, 2014, the Aerospace manufacturer company Orbital ATK was scheduled to transport 5,000 pounds of cargo inside of an unmanned Cygnus spacecraft to the International Space Station. Cygnus was strapped to an Antares rocket that exploded 15 seconds after lift off from a launch pad in Virginia.

Later investigations revealed that the failure began with the rocket's two AJ26 engines. It was likely a flaw in the engine design that led a spinning rotor to touch something it wasn't supposed to, triggering the explosion, Orbital engineers later concluded.The explosion destroyed the Antares rocket, the Cygnus spacecraft, and the 5,000 pounds of cargo inside. The explosion caused $15.2 million in damage to the launch pad alone.

Photographer Joel Kowsky caught the whole thing on camera, snapping some incredible photos that NASA recently released on Flickr. They're a humble reminder of just how dangerous space can be.

Wall Street's party may be over.

It's getting harder for big banks to place loans for big buyout deals, and that could have major implications on Wall Street.

Banks are having trouble placing billions of dollars' worth of loans to support big deals, and they are marking debt down to the investors they are shopping it to, The Wall Street Journal reported on Monday.

These loans often fuel the huge buyout deals that help generate big fees for the banks. One of the few bright spots in big banks' third-quarter results was the outperformance of advisory businesses.

At the same time banks are having trouble selling their riskiest M&A loans, regulators are beginning to focus on loans made to underperforming energy companies.

This vertical forest skyscraper will be covered in thousands of plants. Italian architecture firm Stefano Boeri Architetti is taking it's award-winning design, known as "The Tower of the Cedars", to Lausanne, Switzerland.

There will be over 24,000 on plants on all sides of the 384-foot tower, including 6,000 shrubs and 100 green cedars. Known for their durability and imposing size, the cedar trees will cover the building's facade. That makes it the first high-rise building in the world to feature exclusively evergreen trees, the company says. The same water that flows through the building's plumbing system gets diverted back onto the porches to feed the plants. Most of the units in the 36-floor building will be apartments, ranging in size from two to five rooms, along with a gymnasium, office spaces, and a panoramic restaurant on the top floor. Construction begins in 2017. 
From Singapore to South Korea to Australia, and now Switzerland, vertical forests are becoming more common. They coincide with the rise of vertical farms, which serve as a testament to the world's shrinking supply of fertile ground.

Are Japan's insanely tiny homes the future of cities?

Facebook just gave us a new glimpse into how it's going to deliver the web from solar-powered planes that shoot lasers

The company's CTO, Mike Schroepfer, described how Facebook is about to begin real-world testing of its new system to deliver broadband internet globally via solar-powered "Aquila" planes that stay aloft in space for three months at a time and communicate with lasers.

Each Aquila plane will have the wing of a Boeing 737 and fly up to 90,000 feet for three months at a time. Each plane is incredibly light, and its engines will be powered by solar panels. The planes will receive broadband signals from the nearest city with internet service, beamed up via laser. The World Health Organisation (WHO) has declared that processed meat can cause cancer. 
The WHO says it has "sufficient evidence" to back its claims, and as a result, the UN is adding processed meats such as bacon, lamb, and sausages to its list of cancer-causing substances, despite the risk being small. 
It's estimated that up to 50,000 cancer-related deaths a year could be attributable to diets rich in red meat. 
Meat industry groups are arguing that meat forms part of a balanced diet and that cancer risk assessments need to be set in a broader context of environmental and lifestyle factors.

Red meat was classified as a "probable" carcinogen in its group 2A list that also contains glyphosate, the active ingredient in many weedkillers.

China uses these yak patrol teams to enforce claims over its disputed western borders.

Many of the country's most remote areas are incredibly difficult for humans to reach unaided. 
This is especially true along China's western border with Pakistan. Here, China's Xinjiang Province soars into the sky as it meets the Pamir Mountains ‚Äî one of the highest mountain ranges in the world. 
Faced with a lack of roads, extremely adverse terrain, and incredibly cold weather, the Chinese soldiers and their yaks are responsible for securing this mountain range.

Despite the remoteness of the border, the patrols are of important political significance. The border was originally contested between India, Pakistan, and China. However, an agreement solidified Pakistan and China's border.

India does not recognise the deal and still claims portions of the land as its own.

The distribution of global wealth is getting more unequal every year, according to a huge study by Credit Suisse.

Photos that show how insanely crowded China has become. 
China's population was approaching 1 billion when it enforced a one-child-per-family policy in the late 1970s. Exceptions were only made in the cases of ethnic minorities and rural couples, who were sometimes allowed two children.

The law is not the most popular, and there have been some unintended consequences, including a skewing of the population towards males and a disproportionate representation of elderly people.

Still, many argue that it has been important for the country, as it has helped reduce famine and limited a population that was rapidly growing.

This is Sealand, one of the world's smallest micronations. It is located 7.5 miles from Great Britain.

Though it is not recognised by the UK, it is effectively autonomous since it wasn't located in British territorial waters when it was established in the late 1960s.

Nearly 50 years since this man-made platform split from the United Kingdom, Sealand is still going strong. The micronation has its own royal family, who are also the island's only residents, as well as its own currency.

Sealand was founded in 1967 when former British army Major Roy Bates took over the fort with the idea of setting up a pirate radio station, keeping others who had the same idea at bay. Bates declared the "Principality of Sealand," titling himself Prince Roy, and his wife Princess Joan. The fort has been effectively independent ever since.

The site was previously known as HM Fort Roughs, a military installation built during the Second World War. It was part of a string of other defensive structures called the Maunsell Forts, built to protect south-eastern England against Nazi Germany's naval threat.

50 human skeletons have been found propping up drainage pipes under Westminster Abbey in London.

The remains are thought to be from either the 11th or 12th century and were found in a medieval burial ground situated beneath the iconic building. 
Most of the bones were adult but a child's remains were also found in a wooden coffin. The child is thought to have been roughly three years old and the coffin suggests he was most likely a person of a high status. 
The skeletons were moved there during the reign of Henry III when workers began construction on the new abbey, which also explains the square holes found in several skulls, probably created by workmen during the build. 
Researchers plan to find out their age, health and where they came from thanks to high levels of preservation. Once research is complete, they will be reburied in Westminster Abbey.

This map shows the routes of Europe's refugee nightmare ‚Äî and how it's getting worse.

The distribution of refugees among the members of the 28-member EU has been far from equal. Most refugees are trying to reach rich countries with generous immigration policies like Sweden and Germany, and many Eastern European countries are refusing to take in any refugees.

Most try to reach the Schengen area, 26 countries that have abolished border control and allowed free movement of people and goods.

Archaeologists have uncovered the remains of a massive stone monument buried beneath an area of land just two miles from Stonehenge.

The monument, thought to be an ancient ritual arena, is made up of 90 huge stones, with each one measuring up to 4.5 metres tall. The stones are now lying flat but are thought to have stood upright before being knocked over by Neolithic builders. 
The hidden arrangement was most likely hauled into place over 4,500 years ago and was uncovered using ground-penetrating radar.

The fragments of 60 more buried stones, or the massive foundation pits in which they stood, reveal the full extent of the monument which follows the perimeter of a massive bank in Durrington Walls, the site of a large Neolithic settlement. 
Above is a generated image of what the monument will have looked like when intact.

Every day, thousands of people in Berlin walk past this inconspicuous set of doors in the Gesundbrunnen Underground railway station. But few people know what lies behind.

Behind these green doors is a vast network of abandoned tunnels used as an air raid shelter during the second world war. 
Berliners spent their waking hours in these cold, damp tunnels. The rooms were cramped, air supplies were depleted, and the constant clanging of air vents and overhead bombings made for appalling living conditions.

The hideaway has been immaculately preserved by Berliner Unterwelten, a group of more than 350 history enthusiasts from all walks of life who document and research the city's historical underground sites.

Knee-deep in the shifting sands of the Namib Desert in Namibia, the abandoned village of Kolmanskop stands as a haunting testament to German colonization of the early 20th century.

The town sprung up around a diamond-mining operation and quickly became known as one of the richest towns in southern Namibia, a German colony until World War I.

The town had numerous amenities including a hospital, casino, ice factory, and electrical plant, and even its own swimming pool.

But with Germany losing World War I and diamond production moving elsewhere, the town soon lost its prosperity and was entirely abandoned by 1954. Now it survives as an attraction with guided tours bringing tourists through the empty houses filling with sand as the desert slowly reclaims the town.

If you're wondering why it's so difficult for you to hold down a job, you might consider taking a personality assessment.

Science suggests there's one personality type that's more likely to be unemployed than others.

A new report from Truity Psychometrics, a provider of online personality and career assessments, found that, overall, being a "Perceiver" significantly predicts your tendency to be jobless.

ISFPs (people with a preference for Introversion, Sensing, Feeling, and Perceiving) were the most likely of all 16 personality types to report being unemployed. And INFPs, INTPs, ENTPs, and ESFPs were all more likely than average to report that they were out of a job, according to the report.

Switzerland's central bank lost $51 billion and the franc is getting hammered.

How does a central bank, which can essentially print its own money, get hit with such a loss?

The SNB was the master of its own downfall here. The bank's foreign-currency reserves suffered a huge devaluation when it abandoned a policy to cap the value of the franc against the euro earlier this year.

The bank had been buying euros to maintain a minimum exchange rate of 1.20 Swiss francs to the euro.

When the bank scrapped the policy on January 15, market forces took over and pushed up the value of the franc, devaluing all those recently bought euros at a stroke.

Read more at businessinsider.com

Toshiba CEO resigns over massive accounting scandal

Toshiba CEO Hisao Tanaka resigned on Tuesday, according to CNN, after an internal investigation that revealed the company had been massively overinflating its profits.

Norio Sasaki, vice chairman of the board, and Atsutoshi Nishida, an adviser to the company, will also leave, CNN said.

Chairman Masashi Muromachi will take over as interim president, Bloomberg reported.

A report by independent investigators released on Monday said Toshiba had overstated its operating profit by 151.8 billion yen ($1.22 billion) over several years, roughly triple Toshiba's initial estimate. Tanaka and his predecessor, Sasaki, were aware of the overstatement of profits, it said.

The investigators interrogated 200 Toshiba staffers, according to the Financial Times:

In an 82-page summary of its findings, a panel of external lawyers and accountants detailed what it said were "institutional" accounting malpractices and a corporate culture in which employees were afraid to speak out against bosses' push for increasingly unachievable profits.

There existed a corporate culture at Toshiba where it was impossible to go against the boss' will, the report said. It highlighted a systematic involvement including by top management and a deliberate attempt to inflate the appearance of net profit.

'Rome is on the verge of collapse'

It may boast the Trevi Fountain, the Spanish Steps and the glories that were ancient Rome, but the city is now in chronic decline, its business leaders and inhabitants have warned.

The Eternal City is facing crisis, with its administration engulfed in corruption scandals and debt, its roads scarred by pot-holes, the main airport partially closed and a growing immigration crisis .

For generations, the Italian capital has rested on past glories rather than built on them but now its multiple problems have come to a head.

Drivers on the metro system are on a go-slow in a protest over pay and conditions, hundreds of flights into Fiumicino, the main airport, have been cancelled due to a fire that broke out in a terminal back in May, and temperatures have soared this week to over 100F (37.7C), making daily life even more hellish than normal.

The White House may have made a stunning contradiction right after sealing the Iran 
Republicans skeptical of the Iran nuclear deal are widely pointing to what they call a contradiction from Ben Rhodes, a White House deputy national security adviser, to make their case that the agreement is flawed.
On Tuesday, Rhodes discussed the deal's terms for the inspections of Iranian facilities related to the country's nuclear program.

We never sought in this negotiation the capacity for so-called 'anytime, anywhere,' where you could basically go anywhere in the country, Rhodes said in a CNN interview on Tuesday.

Under the final deal, the inspection rules differ between specifically nuclear facilities, such as uranium-enrichment sites, and other sensitive facilities that are not primarily nuclear in purpose, such as military installations.

According to CBS, a total of 24 days could elapse between the time inspectors first request access to a suspicious site and the time they are allowed entry.

Iran agreed to this and various other limits on its program in exchange for the rollback of economic sanctions.

The problem is that Rhodes previously used the phrase "anytime, anywhere" multiple times to describe the White House's negotiating objectives with Iran. Mediaite flagged two such instances on Wednesday.

We've finally added Pluto to the family portrait of the solar system

NASA's New Horizons spacecraft made history Tuesday morning when it became the first to reach Pluto after nearly 10 years and 3 billion miles of space travel.

Even though Pluto was demoted from a planet to a dwarf planet in 2006, it's still part of the Solar System. It orbits at the very edge of it, in a mysterious zone of icy objects known as the Kuiper Belt.

We barely had an idea of what Pluto looked like until New Horizons began closing in on it this month. Now that the spacecraft is beaming back incredibly detailed, high-resolution images, we're starting to learn a lot more about one of the last unexplored worlds in the Solar System.

Hillary Clinton just called out the economic problem of the next decade

Hillary Clinton just brought the most important economic issue of the next decade into the mainstream: the gig economy.

The gig, or on-demand, economy is the new favorite business model coming out of Silicon Valley.

It is relevant to companies such as Uber, which streamlines work for its drivers and takes a cut of their fares but lets them work on their own schedule. It's a little bit like a blend between the regular employment model and the freelancer model.

Whether we like it or not, the gig economy seems to be everywhere. More and more Americans are turning to this semi-freelance way of making a living.

A study from the software company Intuit a few years ago estimated that as much as 40% of the American workforce could be freelancers, independent contractors, or consultants by the year 2020. It's a major, major economic shift.

The Penleigh and Essendon Grammar Middle Girls School (PEGS) building takes design, innovation, function, and customization in it‚Äôs own hands. The space aims to establish a layered and varied system that‚Äôs able to respond to specifities of the different student bodies. The scale and shapes change throughout, taking away certain views but also unveiling others. It is a system of bells and whistles, with plenty of surprises while still being able to work efficiently.

100PP is a new eight-story office block by the Ministry of Design is made up of striated layers and shifted floorplates. The building faces the sea on one side of it, and on the other is the highway. Offices inside have been popular for attracting graphic designers, textile designers, and animation studios. On the exterior, there are strips of light so as to bring out the layering more.

The World Architecture Festival ‚Äî held this year in Singapore ‚Äî won't name 2015's Building of the Year until November, but the nominations are officially in. With 338 buildings in the running, we combed through the contenders and made our own shortlist. From a ribbon-inspired wedding chapel in Hiroshima to Zaha Hadid's ¬£240 million London Aquatics Centre, there are the 27 buildings that really jumped out and caught our eye. The first, in this photo, is a vertical village in Singapore is a combination of spaces that are both shared and private, ushering in a bigger focus on bringing together the community. There are 31 six-story apartment blocks spread out across eight courtyards (1,040 residential units in total, varying in size).

In 2009, the Department of Transportation began requiring all airports to build designated pet relief areas. So JetBlue partnered with the architecture and design firm Gensler to create a rooftop deck at JFK International available to all passengers ‚Äî including dogs. Gensler architect and principal Ty Osbaugh realized it could eliminate all that hassle simply by moving the pet relief area to the other side of security. Then the possibilities started opening up. Last year's expansion to T5, a one-story international wing known as T5i, had ample space that wasn't being used ‚Äî on the roof. "We started planning for that," Osbaugh tells Business Insider, "and it just kind of grew legs."

With Greece unable to pay its debts and the IOC now struggling to find countries willing to host the Olympics, 2004 might be viewed as one of the last Olympics of an era when democratic nations saw the games as a worthwhile investment. The venues for softball, beach volleyball, and kayaking are all overrun with weeds.

The 2004 Athens Olympics went nearly $15 billion over its initial $1.6 billion budget. The majority of the cost overruns fell on the Greek government, which built all the expensive, highly specific buildings you need to host the Olympics ‚Äî a village, a media center, an Olympic stadium, a canoe/kayak slalom center, etc. When the athletes went home at the end of August 2004, organizers learned a cruel lesson ‚Äî Athens has absolutely no use for a canoe/kayak slalom center. Amid an economic crisis that has seen other parts of Athens diminished, many of their 2004 Olympic stadiums have long since become white elephants.

Nothing can top the show on the East River during the 39th Annual Macy's 4th of July Fireworks, the country‚Äôs largest display of Independence Day fireworks. This year expanded to two locations on the East River, four barges stationed near Midtown and one double-barge south of the Brooklyn Bridge - providing viewers in Manhattan, Queens, and Brooklyn with pyrotechnic entertainment. During the 25-minute show, a dazzling 40,000 are fired off. For the best views of fireworks in both locations, tune into NBC‚Äôs two-hour national broadcast starting soon at 9:20pm EST.

Ushering in America‚Äôs 239th birthday from the nation‚Äôs capital, the National Mall Fourth of July Celebration stands as one of the country‚Äôs largest fireworks displays. Hundreds of thousands of people descend on the capital each year, filling the National Mall to maximum capacity, where the fireworks blast off from the Reflecting Pool. The 17.5-minute firework show lights up the D.C. skyline, illuminating the Capitol, the White House, and the Washington Monument. Barry Manilow headlines the festivities this year, along with the National Symphony Orchestra. Both the concert and fireworks are broadcast throughout the country on PBS for those who would rather avoid the crowds.

There‚Äôs more than one reason why the shores of Atlantic City are popular this July, as fireworks light up the waterfront sky on July 4th (they even get a head start the night before, too). Two ocean barges fire off a 15-minute showcase choreographed to music. Hotels such as the Borgata and Harrah‚Äôs serve as the backdrop for the main night‚Äôs 15-minute fireworks show.

Known for its huge fireworks display, Estes Park of Colorado (on the outside Rocky Mountain National Park) starts its Go 4th Festival on July 3rd with the Tunes, Treats and Toasts party featuring a pig roast, live music, and a beer garden. July 4th brings both an annual pancake breakfast and bull-riding show. Readers clearly wanted to stick around, ranking Estes Park in the top 10 for its motels, historic hotels, and vacation homes. Your choices include the romantic 14-suite Della Terra Mountain Chateau.

With its ponderosa pines, frontier spirit, and easy access to the Grand Canyon, the Arizona town of Flagstaff won the medal of honor in T+L‚Äôs Independence Day contest. It also made the top 10 for its town squares, and the centerpiece of its July 4th celebration is a parade through downtown - along with fireworks, a fun run, a concert by the Flagstaff Symphony Orchestra, and ‚ÄúFlagstaff Art in the Park,‚Äù a juried art and fine crafts show in downtown‚Äôs Wheeler Park. Flagstaff won high marks in the survey for its parks and hosts a downtown Art Walk monthly.

Bend, Oregon has been crowned number one in town pride before, and one reason may be its creative celebration of the Fourth: an all-day party in Drake Park with old-fashioned gunnysack races, hula-hoop contests, and, the pi√®ce de r√©sistance, the July 4th Pet Parade. Dating back to the 1930s, the parade features costumed kids and pets walking or riding in wagons. Bend also ranked highly for family-friendly hotels, such as the River House Hotel, sitting on the Deschutes River.

A 65-foot infinity pool sits out back of Calvin Klein‚Äôs new home. The views of Los Angeles from it are absolutely stunning. Before you get to this area, however, you must traverse a bridge over a waterfall and reflecting pool to enter the home to begin with, with the bridge's intended purpose to be to "slow the participant down and create a feeling of separation from the street behind.‚Äù Lights shoot up from the water features to welcome you.

The incredibly spacious master suite has the best view of all. In total, the home now owned by Calvin Klein has five bedrooms and seven bathrooms. Terraces attached to the master suite make use of the moving glass walls (many of which are fully retractable). The ceilings throughout the home measure 13 feet high. Most rooms are completely open to allow sunlight to flow throughout the home.

It looks like designer Calvin Klein is apt to spend a little more time in LA. He just bought a spectacular, 9,300-square-foot home in the Hollywood Hills area for $25 million. The five-bedroom mansion fits squarely in the contemporary architectural style and features sliding glass walls, 13-foot-high ceilings, an infinity pool, and a bridged entryway over a waterfall and reflecting pool. Other amenities include an eight-car garage and a 12-seat home theater.

Through the Instagram account he started five years ago, the unique images of pilot @AdamSenatori have found a new, wider audience. He was one of the first photographers that the company featured on the Instagram blog, and he‚Äôs gained around 850,000 followers. While social media usually moves at lightning speed, Senatori's workflow is usually much slower, as he usually shoots with a Medium Format Digital Hasselblad.

Pilot @AdamSenatori tells Business Insider that it was his iPhone that first sparked the idea to take pictures from the air. ‚ÄúAfter I left the airlines and was flying for fun, I started taking some quick shots with my iPhone and that‚Äôs when it triggered that I had something unique. I could fly, or had friends that could fly me, and take photos.‚Äù

Ever since he was a kid, @AdamSenatori  dreamed of being a pilot. After fulfilling that dream by becoming a commercial airline captain, Senatori was unfortunately laid off and forced to take a buyout. Faced with a new challenge, he looked for other opportunities and made the transition from commercial aviator to commercial photographer. Now he shoots incredible aerial images like this one.
There are some interesting perks to Google‚Äôs Data Center spaces, too. In this one in Finland, a conference room is located just outside a sauna area available to all employees.

What's behind the server aisle at a Google data center? There are hundreds of fans cooling down the servers. The green lights show the server status. The company custom designs the servers to be compact and energy efficient. To make sure users can have quick access to data, Google stores each piece of data on at least two servers.

These colorful pipes are used to send water to cool the Google data centers. That's a G-Bike employees use to move around data centers. 
Extra copies of the most important data on Google‚Äôs digital tapes are stored in a place called the "Tape Library.‚Äù There are robotic arms that can automatically load and unload tapes. When a backup tape breaks, it is immediately destroyed with a disk-crusher.

This outdoor fireplace is one of nine scattered throughout the main house and guest houses of this unfinished East Hampton compound, which packs 11 parcels for the price of one. Minutes away from East Hampton Village, the 18,000-square-foot, English manor-style home sits on approximately 23 acres of land. Call it a family mansion or an equestrian estate, either way the listing price is $55 million.

If you're a fan of cooking and food, you'll definitely be jealous of Food52's new digs in New York City. A bit like a social network exclusively for foodies, Food52 is a recipe site and cooking product marketplace where you can search for meal preparation tips and buy all of the gear you need to cook at home. We recently paid a visit to their brand-new headquarters in Chelsea. From a gorgeous test kitchen to food books all around, we were hungry from the moment we walked in.

When you think of the world's most prosperous shopping streets, you probably don't think of Greece. But before the double whammy of the 2008 financial crisis and the 2010-2012 eurozone crisis, Athens was home to some of the most prime retail space on the planet. The price of retail space in the area has fallen by nearly half since 2007, and the space has lost a lot of its former glory.

These Google servers handle everything from processing billions of searches and hosting Youtube videos, to protecting your email from virus attacks. Google says its fiber optic networks run at speeds that are more than 200,000 times faster than a typical home Internet connection.

Data centers basically power all of Google's services, so they need to run 24 hours a day. Google has data centers in 14 different locations, including The Netherlands, Singapore, and Chile. This is the one in Finland. At first, they may look just like any other Google office. But once you get to the back, you'll see racks and racks of servers and computer storage.

Every time you use a Google product, you‚Äôre connecting to one of its data centers located around the world. Google has been notoriously secretive about it, but recently it‚Äôs been sharing some photos and videos of its state-of-the-art data centers.

In travel photography, paying attention to the light translates into keeping in mind the time of day you're seeing things. This photo was shot during Golden Hour, which adds depth and feeling to the photograph. It also pushes past the pretty postcard: it's less about the Eiffel Tower itself here, and more about the experience of picnicking on its lawn. The three times of the day that shooter Whitney Tressel encourages folks to explore are sunrise, golden hour, and the time right after sunset.

When asked about the most important aspect of travel photography in particular, Whitney Tressel says that "It's about visually showing a sense of place. That can be literally taken as landscapes or architecture, but it can also mean the people there, or the different cultural traditions, or the different ways of life. Or sometimes it's the similarities. Sometimes you think you're going to a place that is so different, and you realize how similar it actually is.‚Äù

Whitney Tressel is a hybrid travel photographer and photo editor who has dozens of cross country road trips and travels under her belt, documented for the likes of Esquire, Budget Travel, and Hemispheres. Professing that she's always had the travel bug, she's rarely not on the road - as summers see her teaching National Geographic's Student Expedition courses, which have taken her and her pupils to far flung locales like Paris, Barcelona, Costa Rica, and next month, Australia. She gave us some tips on improving your photography game so stay tuned to the upcoming posts.

Being in love isn't all in our heads: there are chemicals can cause reactions throughout the body, which might help explain that tingly-all-over feeling we get when we see a loved one, or the "high" we feel after we've met that special someone. "The hormone that is most specific to feeling in love, that is most specific to the social response, is oxytocin. And a closely related neuropeptide called vasopressin,‚Äù says Abigail Marsh, psychologist. Illustration by @bi_graphics.

"This mechanism is part of the compensation system that pushes us to romantic pursuit,‚Äù says Lucy Brown. Ph.D, from the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in New York. "This obsessive and compulsive attitude that for the same reasons appears among drug addicts is maybe not good for the individual, but serves our human gender exactly like other impulses of mammals.‚Äù Illustration by @bi_graphics.

Love may not be a drug, but it can certainly feel like one. Being in love floods our brains with chemicals that can induce feelings of everything from pleasure to intense focus and attachment. "Some of the reason that love feels good is because a lot of the feel-good hormones are involved. Dopamine is the reward-seeking ‚Äî energized, excited ‚Äî neurotransmitter in the striatum that is definitely involved in feeling in love,‚Äù says psychologist Abigail Marsh from Georgetown University. Illustration by @bi_graphics.

The Great Pyramids of Giza in Egypt are the only of the seven ancient world wonders still in existence. Not to mention the oldest one of them as well, which makes it even more impressive, built around approximately 2580-2560 BC.

The Sahara desert is the largest desert on the African continent and the third largest overall. It covers most of North Africa with over 3.5 million square miles of land. The northeasterly winds of the area have the potential to reach hurricane level and usually sand storms emerge. It‚Äôs not a surprise that half of the desert gets less than an inch of rain per year (the rest gets up to 4 inches), but when it does rain it really pours.

One of the most popular trails in Moab, Utah is the Poison Spider Mesa Trail. One of the favorite activities of visitors to do on it is mountain biking (only expert bikers should take it on, however. If you end up going, you probably want to account for at least half a day. It‚Äôs a bit of a difficult terrain to navigate for anyone, but if you know what you‚Äôre doing than it can be quite the experience.

This estate shelters an 8,400-square-foot main house with three bedrooms, a guest house, and a 3,000-square-foot beach house with two bedrooms, an office, and a kitchen. The property is a boater's dream: it's located on Florida's southernmost eastern barrier and it has a private dock. At the end of a long day, new owner John Malone can kick back next to his outdoor fire pit and listen to the sound of the tumbling waves.

Built in 1997, this 22,057-square-foot home sits on over nine acres of land with Atlantic and Intracoastal views. The property stretches 506 feet along the ocean and 510 feet along the Intracoastal. It is the former home of Horst Brandst√§tter (the founder of Playmobil) and this beachfront estate has it all. There is a pristine outdoor deck is the perfect spot for a summer cocktail party, as well as a pool (meanwhile being close to Jupiter Island Beach), a putting green, and a garage for a golf cart.

John Malone recently added the beach house estate to his collection. The chairman of Liberty Media Corp. paid $38 million for a mansion on Jupiter Island. The living room of John Malone's new estate is built on a turntable, bringing new meaning to the phrase, "the room is spinning.‚Äù

Los Glaciares National Park in Patagonia, Argentina, is home to the largest ice mantle outside of Antarctica. Glaciers feed into the nearby Lake Argentino to create a breathtaking view. Established in the late 1930s, the park is around 1.8 million acres large (however, that is only second place in the country).

Yellowstone National Park, located in Wyoming and Montana, has half of the world‚Äôs geothermal features with over 10,000 examples, the world‚Äôs largest concentration of geysers, and an impressive variety of wildlife. It contains over 3,500 square miles of space and is one of the most popular big parks in the United States.

The Iguazu National Park, located on the Northeastern tip of Argentina and bordering the Brazilian state of Parana, hosts a semicircular waterfall which actually forms the border between the two countries and has a diameter of almost 984 feet. Nearby in the rainforest there is a wide range of plants, as well as a variety of animal species.

‚ÄúThe first year is the hardest ‚Äî if you get through that and want to continue, then the road is for you.‚Äù Though living out of a van isn't easy, it serves well for Alison Turner‚Äôs lifestyle. "Everything you decide to bring along must have a function. There isn‚Äôt room for things you don‚Äôt use." Weather is an important factor, and Turner generally travels following the good kind. "What the weather is outside is what it will be in the van. I have camped in over 100 degrees and below freezing.‚Äù

Photography has been an integral part of Alison Turner‚Äôs travels. Since beginning her journey, Turner‚Äôs client list has grown, and her work has been shown in galleries across the US. Between her GoPro, Instagram, and DSLR, she‚Äôs documented and shared her journey, inspired by the people she‚Äôs met along the way, the sweeping landscapes, and, of course, her dog Max.

In 2008, Alison Turner quit her job in ad sales, hit the road with her rescue dog, Max, and didn't look back. Over the past seven years, Turner and Max have circled the US three times, driven over 100,000 miles, and made several trips to their favorite destination, the American Southwest. ‚ÄúEver since I can remember, I have been independent and curious,‚Äù Turner told Business Insider. ‚ÄúBeing on the open road is a feeling I can‚Äôt get anywhere else. It‚Äôs a feeling of freedom,‚Äù Turner said.

Do you believe that good design can change the world? Business Insider is hiring a paid intern to cover the world of design innovation. It will be your job to find the most interesting angles on what's happening in the worlds of architecture, design for the developing world, product design, urban design, and everything in between. In this image is the building is the Metropol Parasol in Spain, shot by LWYang, in the old quarter of the Seville village. It finished being built four years ago. It‚Äôs unusual and unique design was devised by German architect J√ºrgen Mayer-Hermann. You can find more about the position on our website if you‚Äôre interested in reporting for us!

"I should have known better, but when my boyfriend suggested a multi-day bike tour through Tuscany, across the Chianti Hills specifically, I was more focused on visions of myself sipping Chianti than slogging up hills on a bike. Big mistake,‚Äù says Sophie-Claire Hoeller in her article for Business Insider. Her tips for booking your own trip are to figure out your budget, decide on a duration, choose whether to go alone, pick the terrain/difficulty level, and get the right gear! Be prepared.

Beyond its beautiful beaches, bays, and lagoons, there's another type of eye candy that's native to the Hamptons: gorgeous, hidden real estate. Tucked at the end of snaking driveways, with huge shrubs blocking any chance of a roadside view, some of the East End's most breathtaking homes are rarely seen ‚Äî at least, until now. Aerial photographer Jeff Cully of EEFAS captures the area's most exclusive enclaves, and the mansions hidden within. This photo is taken heading east over Sagaponack Pond in the Sagaponack town of the same name, which was labeled the most expensive small town in the country in 2010.

There is an 8,000-square-foot spa pavilion next to the Mountain Resort, where inside you can start your mornings with a swim in the 20x63 lap pool. There are also sauna booths with privacy curtains, a game room, outdoor decks with lounge chairs, a living area with a 25-foot tall fireplace, and a spacious bedroom.

The exposed logs in the Schweitzer Mountain Resort interior create a warm ambiance. Hand-painted tiles, like the ones above the living room fireplace, are a recurring design accent. It is a 918-acre Buck Quarter Ranch in Cusick, Washington. Built in 2004, this 12,017-square-foot, custom-built log home has four bedrooms, four bathrooms, and one partial bath.

You've never seen a ranch like this before. Though it neighbors Idaho travel spots like Schweitzer Mountain Resort and Lake Pend Oreille, Buck Quarter Ranch is a vacation destination in itself. In fact, if you're not in the market for another home, you could easily turn it into a luxury resort. Even better, the ranch is a turnkey property with multiple furnished homes and recreation perks like a spa pavilion and a rifle range.

The naturally terraced thermal springs of Hierapolis-Pamukkale in the province of Denizli in western Turkey, date as far back as the second century B.C. Formed by calcite in the water, the hot springs look like stunning white clouds. The name ‚ÄúPamukkale‚Äù translates over to ‚Äúcotton castle‚Äù in Turkish. The flowing water leaves residue of carbonate materials in its path.

Vietnam‚Äôs Phong Nha-Ke Bang National Park, located in the middle of the Annamite Mountain Range in Quang Binh province in the center of country, is home to the oldest karst (or landscapes formed from soluble rocks and characterized by caves and sinkholes) formations in Asia. Dating back over 400 million years, it contains more than 64 miles of caves and underground rivers.

G√∂reme National Park and the Rock Sites of Cappadocia is a volcanic landscape created entirely from erosion that eventually formed mountain ridges, valleys, and pinnacles nicknamed ‚Äúfairy chimneys‚Äù across Cappadocia, Turkey. The first signs of activity there date back to the 4th century at which time small anchorite communities, acting on the teachings of Basileios the Great, Bishop of Kayseri, began inhabiting cells hewn in the rock. In later periods, in order to resist Arab invasions, they began banding together into troglodyte villages or subterranean towns such as Kaymakli or Derinkuyu which served as places of refuge.

The press conference room for the Council of Europe in Brussels, Belgium is a bit more public-facing. The intergovernmental organization, which seeks to promote cooperation between European states, uses this room to spread its message to the press.

The library at Humboldt University of Berlin counts its power in books. With 6.5 million volumes and 9,000 held magazines and journals, it's one of the largest libraries in Germany. It was one of the biggest university libraries in the country during the Weimar Republic government reign. It had around 800,000 books at the time and luckily no books were burned by the Nazi‚Äôs during their time in power after. Another library building is going to be built nearby in the center of Berlin soon.

UN Room XXIV is a 260-person capacity conference room in the UN's Geneva office. Though it lacks the glitz of the New York headquarters, it's certain that some important meetings are held here. The UNOG is one of four sites that the UN (and the second biggest). It also hosts the UNCTAD, OCHA, and ECE.

The Grenada Underwater Sculpture Park in Grenada, and the Museo Subacu√°tico de Arte, located off the coast of Isla Mujeres in Mexico's Riviera Maya, were created by artists to promote the continued growth of coral and underwater life by using marine-grade cement. MUSA is home to as many as 500 submerged whimsical sculptures. 
Two-thirds of our world is made up of water, which is why travel operators are starting to integrate underwater attractions into travel. It's the next frontier in the travel industry, as the area underneath our oceans has largely yet to be explored. 
There is already an array of underwater restaurants, resorts, tours, and transportation available around the world today.

There's a new market for privatized submarine experiences. British travel company Oliver's Travels created a specially adapted submarine in St. Lucia known as Lovers Deep, an underwater vessel where couples can spend the night in a private accommodation. The submarine, which is already available for use, is staffed by a crew of three, a captain, chef, and butler, and can be taken to locations chosen by the customer. 
It's not cheap, at ¬£175,000 per night ($274,694), but each interior of the private submarine room is set to be designed and manufactured to your specifications and includes a two-person bathroom and double bedroom with ocean views.

The Conrad Maldives Rangali Island in the Maldives. opened its restaurant's doors in 2005, allowing guests to have their meals in a clear acrylic tube 5 meters (16 ft.) under the Indian Ocean. The restaurant is surrounded with 180-degree views of fish, sharks, and coral reefs
.

The 2016 presidential candidates have been reacting to the #GayMarriage ruling on Twitter. While not every one of them agrees with the decision, Hillary Clinton is all for the progressive step in the country‚Äôs history. She even updated her campaign logo for the occasion and tweeted that she is ‚ÄúProud to celebrate a historic victory for marriage equality‚Äî& the courage & determination of LGBT Americans who made it possible.‚Äù #LoveWins

The @WhiteHouse is going rainbow in honor of the Supreme Court's legalization of #GayMarriage. Earlier today, the Supreme Court ruled 5-4 that "the Fourteenth Amendment requires a state to license a marriage between two people of the same sex," Business Insider reported. In celebration, the official White House Facebook page changed it's profile picture. The graphic features the iconic White House vibrantly decorated with five rainbow colors.

Gay Marriage is legal nationwide. On Friday, the Supreme Court ruled 5-4 that the Constitution's Fourteenth Amendment guarantees due process and equal protection under the law. Therefore, states cannot ban same-sex marriages. In his ruling, Anthony Kennedy - the Associate Justice of the Supreme Court - expressed why #GayMarriage is necessary for true equality. "As the state itself makes marriage all the more precious by the significance it attaches to it, exclusion from that status has the effect of teaching that gays and lesbians are unequal in important respects." #LoveWins

The Havasupai Falls, located in the Havasupai Reservation of Coconino County at the southwest corner of the Grand Canyon National Park, are known for their clear blue waterfalls adorned with travertine columns. Hidden amidst the popular Grand Canyon, the Havasupai Falls are not as nearly as crowded as the park considering the eight mile hiking trail you‚Äôll need to take to Supai Village.

Pueblo Bonito, located in the Chaco Culture National Historical Park in northern New Mexico, includes remnants of the Puebloan people who built over 600 rooms in the area between AD 828 and 1126. It‚Äôs said to be the most crucial part of the canyon, one that you cannot miss out on if you‚Äôre visiting (only a 0.6 mile roundtrip).

Reflection Canyon is found on the side of Lake Powell, bordering Utah and Arizona, in the Glen Canyon National Recreation Area. The natural wonder is known for stunning colorful reflections in its waters, but is tough to access considering you typically have to go either by boat or through the strenuous 55 mile road called the Hole-in-the-Rock Road. 
Besides its more well-known locations, the United States is home to stunning sites that offer an escape from the masses.

Another park in Alaska, the Gates of the Arctic National Park and Preserve in Coldfoot is a vast landscape created from years of erosion that molded valleys, rivers, mountains, and lakes where hikers can also experience aurora-lit night skies in the winter.

The night skies of Great Basin National Park, located five miles west of the town of Baker in east central Nevada, are among one of the darkest in the country. Due to this, the park offers one of the most stunning views of starry skies.

"For a semi-customised superyacht, I would say (it takes) 2.5 years on average and for a fully customised superyacht, depending on the complexity, it would be 3 years onwards,‚Äù says Sara Gioanola, a manager at Heseen Yachts, in a recent interview with us at Business Insider. "We currently are building 10 superyachts at the moment in the shipyard for delivery between 2016-2017 and it's pretty much split 50/50 on semi-customization and full customization." Heseen Yachts is a Dutch company that builds these luxury titans of the sea in a South Netherlands‚Äô shipyard.

You don't need fancy camera equipment to take captivating photographs. The winners of the 8th annual iPhone Photography Awards (IPPAWARDS) submitted images taken using just their iPhone, iPod or iPad camera, and could only use an iOS app to edit it. This winning entry was taken by Jose Luis Saes Martinez of Valencia, Spain.

This beach in Iceland is in the Vik village, one of the wettest places in the country. Puffins even make little hotels to go into during their season of nesting. Many other seabirds also call the beach home. The area‚Äôs summers are short and cool in temperature, but the winters are not too extreme. It gets about 90 inches of rain a year.

The headquarters of the French Communist Party in Paris contains this cavernous meeting hall. The 94-year-old political party's influence has waned in recent years, but it's still a major force in French politics. It's in these rooms where world-changing decisions are made by just a few individuals. These decisions "determine a large part of our collective existence,‚Äù Luca Zanier, photographer, says - which is exactly what he set out to convey in his photo series "Corridors of Power."

The FIFA executive committee meets in this villainous hall in Zurich, Switzerland. The executive committee is the main decision-making organization of FIFA; it is elected during a yearly meeting of FIFA's 209-member congress. Photographer Luca Zanier was granted access to big rooms like this when the buildings were completely empty.

Not everyone gains entrance into the meeting places of the world's most powerful leaders. In the interest of safety, meetings in these rooms - located in tightly secured buildings, sometimes within huge secured complexes - are closed-door affairs. The United Nations General Assembly in the UN Headquarters in New York City is one of the most powerful. Here, representatives from 192 state delegations vote on essential UN regulations and functions.

A dream room for a kid who lives skateboarding is one of three rooms included in this apartment. The penthouse features two full bathrooms and one half bath. Sotheby's describes the duplex apartment as "Dumbo's phenomenal penthouse." It's definitely stylish enough for the starchitect Bjarke Ingels. If the penthouse at 250 Water Street in the exclusive Brooklyn neighborhood of Dumbo looks like it was decorated by an interior designer, that's because it was.

Four private terraces with jaw-dropping city views will allow Bjarke Ingels to watch his 2 WTC masterpiece rise. With 2,344 square feet of outdoor space, Ingels has bought himself four scenic terraces. The terraces boast ample space for furniture, fire pits, planters, and barbecue grills. The spectacular city views will really pay off during the Fourth of July fireworks displays on the East River.

Bjarke Ingels isn't a household name yet. But you probably know his buildings. The Danish starchitect's international architecture firm, Bjarke Ingels Group (BIG), recently snagged the 2 World Trade Center commission. On the heels of his big get, Ingels has acquired some fancy new digs: a gorgeous penthouse in Dumbo, Brooklyn. Double-height ceilings make room for a wall of windows, which fill the apartment with sunlight.

The Standard hotel nests itself right on the High Line. This, in combination with it‚Äôs views over the river, might have been what made the boutique space the Audience Favorite for Jetsetter‚Äôs best hotels in the world. It was finished in 2009 and stands at 18 stories, fitting in 337 guest rooms. At the bottom of it is an outdoor space that both guests and the public can come to grab food from the hotel‚Äôs restaurant, grill, or Biergarten.

For the Best for Communing With Nature category, Jetsetter chose the Lion Sands River Lodge, in the Kruger National Park, that rests in South Africa. They claim that "you need not move far to appreciate extraordinary wildlife, or to marvel at the spectacular riverside view." They have tried to "capture the entrancing spirit of the Sabie River, and always smile at that moment when we see our guests forging their own connection with that special energy that cannot be seen, but can definitely be felt.‚Äù

Jetsetter has just released its list of its Best of the Best Hotel Awards for 2015. To make this list, the hotel booking site looked at over 200 reviews from Jetsetter travel correspondents and narrowed down their choices based on categories like Best Design, Best High-Tech, Best for Foodies, and Best Boutique. For the category of Best Newcomer is the Mondrian London, which was inspired by cruise ships from the 1920s. It is very close to some of London‚Äôs biggest attractions like the Tate Modern.

Cadets from the National Cadet Corps take part in an examination on open ground in the northern Indian city of Allahabad. More than 2,000 cadets on took part in the examination for upper grades. Test-taking appears to be more prominent in certain parts of the world, such as Asia, than in others. Still, whether it‚Äôs youngsters in Aleppo or pet groomers in Changsha, testing‚Äîfrom pre-exam anxiety to post-exam euphoria‚Äîis something that oddly enough, seems to unite us all.

The ritual at its core doesn't vary much: Students sit at a table or a computer desk (or sometimes on the floor), pencil and/or mouse in hand, the clock ticking away mercilessly. Testing has become increasingly notorious in the U.S., to the point that tens of thousands of parents across the country have opted their kids out of standardized tests. In this shot, groomers cut hair of pet dogs as they attend a pet-barber qualification test in Changsha, Hunan province, a couple of months ago.

Examinations, tests, assessments‚Äîwhatever the nomenclature, it‚Äôs hard to imagine schooling without them. Testing is the most popular method of quantifying individuals‚Äô knowledge, often with the intention of objectively measuring aptitude and ability. Test-taking is a dreaded experience that the country‚Äôs kids and young adults share with their counterparts across the globe. Here, an Afghan teacher stands in front of pupils during a year-end examination in a school in the village of Sangarkhel in mountains of Wardak Province, Afghanistan.

Usually when an automaker produces an amazing concept vehicle, it won't ever be mass produced. Mercedes has reversed this trend, responding to consumer demand for a concept they unveiled at the Geneva Auto Show this year. The new Mercedes-Benz G500 4x42 is a new addition to the G class of off-road SUVs already produced by the German luxury automaker. It's quite a car and comes in a whole variety of interesting colors.

Eurostar ‚Äî the train network that connects the UK with France and Belgium ‚Äî introduced its new series of luxurious high speed trains last year, just in time to celebrate its 20th anniversary of cross-channel service. The Eurostar and the channel tunnel it travels through on its trips in and out of Europe have helped shape modern travel in the UK. Called the Eurostar e320 ‚Äî in reference to its 200mph top speed ‚Äî the next generation of super fast trains will continue the legacy of efficient high speed train travel between Britannia and the Continent. According to the Guardian, the first 17 e320 train sets will enter service late next year.

Librarian of Congress James Billington announced this month that he plans to step down from the post he has held for almost 28 years. The Library of Congress is more than a magnificent building full of books. Besides maintaining an unparalleled collection, the librarian oversees the national copyright office and provides research and analysis to Congress ‚Äî all this in a time when production and reproduction of information, music and video is moving faster than ever. The next librarian will need to develop a system to make existing materials searchable online and to digitize material as it comes in.

Smallcakes has 88 stores in 19 states, primarily in the Southeast. The chain sells fresh-baked cupcakes and other sweet treats, including ice cream. It generated nearly $39 million in sales last year, according to Technomic.

The master bath has a freestanding tub. "We added a shower to our second bathroom, so now it‚Äôs much more comfortable to have guests stay over," Tecco said. In another part of the house is the master bedroom, which is large by Manhattan standards and has its own large fireplace. If you have 2.2 million to invest, this wouldn‚Äôt be too shabby a place to rest your head at.

The living room is filled with lots of texture and color. Its best features include a wall-length bookcase and a fireplace. "We struggled to use color in our last apartment in San Francisco, which was all gray and navy, so we really wanted to experiment with color, pattern, and texture in this home," Tecco told Business Insider. The one-bedroom apartment is located on the garden level of a townhouse in the East Village. Hammerbacher and Tecco have direct access to the garden, part of which they share with their neighbors. The kitchen, which they love, opens up to the garden.

A New York City apartment belonging to a noted couple in tech has hit the market for $2.2 million. The owners of the East Village home are Jeff Hammerbacher, an early Facebook employee and cofounder of Cloudera, and his wife Halle Tecco, founder of medical venture fund Rock Health. They bought the apartment from Chloe Sevigny for $1.76 million in 2012. The couple then spent nine months renovating the space. According to Tecco, this office nook used to be a closet.

Mount Fuji, located on Honshu Island, is Japan‚Äôs highest mountain at a staggering 12,389 feet. It's an active stratovolcano, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, and one of Japan's most popular tourist sites.

"We watched movies like 'Indiana Jones,' 'Huck Finn,' 'Star Wars,' 'Swiss Family Robinson,' and 'Hook,' where they had these fantastical buildings. Why can't those be reality? They can: You just gotta build them.‚Äù And that‚Äôs just what @fosterhunting and his friends did. Now he wants to share that feeling and inspiration. "I'm dyslexic, so at a young age, I was really drawn to photo books. I'd go to the library and look at all the books they had. I wouldn't read them; I would just look at all the photos. - (With the book) I wanted to get people inspired to make stuff. Here's a group of people where some of the crew was really experienced woodworkers, but a lot of us weren't, and we just kind of figured it out and it turned out really well."

"I got my first skateboard when I was around 7,‚Äù @fosterhunting told Business Insider. "It's always been a constant in my life. Skating was the first cultural group of people that I really identified with, and because of that, I've always seen the world through that lens. Originally, we were just going to build a small mini-ramp and I was like, 'Why don't we build a bowl?' And it was just kind of like, 'I guess we can!‚Äô It's something that really keeps you young. Two days ago, I had a friend up who was 80 years old and he still skateboards. It's just so cool seeing how something like skateboarding can stay with you through your whole life. So that's what the bowl is for me. I'm going to skate now and I'm going to skate in 20 years.‚Äù

"I didn't want to spend my youth in an office,‚Äù Foster Huntington told Business Insider about quitting a Ralph Lauren job and deciding to travel across the country in a van for years. Being on the road was really great, but he found it harder to be productive. So he decided to slow his wheels for a bit and pursue another dream, this time building a treehouse with his friends that he could live in and work from. The Cinder Cone, as they call it, has been in construction for over a year, and this past month Huntington has ran a Kickstarter to fund a book about the project, which has already reached more than $70,000 ‚Äî more than doubling his goal. "I would never be able to do what I do if I didn't have the channels of the internet."

The Greek island of Santorini sits on the Aegean sea and is easily recognizable from its architecture: a cluster of white stone buildings topped with rich blue roofs that sit on cliffs above the sea. It is one of the Cyclades islands in the Aegean Sea and was devastated by a volcanic eruption in the 16th century B.C.E., forever shaping its rugged landscape and villages.

Couples who are looking for breathtaking scenery but cooler temperatures can head to Spitsbergen in Norway, the Svalbard archipelago's largest and only island that's permanently populated. This remote island in the Arctic Ocean has polar bears, snow-capped mountains, and even the world-famous Northern Lights. Where a couple decides to honeymoon is a personal choice. For some, paradise is lounging on a beach with soft white sand and clear aquamarine water surrounded by palm trees. For others, it's roaming the streets and enjoying the charm of a romantic city like Paris. Either way, chances are you'll find an ideal honeymoon spot in our list of newlywed destinations that are trending now.

Elon Musk‚Äôs Hyperloop idea aims to make travel fast, efficient and affordable. The "executive meeting" capsule (pictured here) is designed to hold eight passengers and features chairs that are fully automated allowing for the passenger to recline to a sleeping position. All of the passenger capsules would also feature digital wall screens called "Tripscenes," which would display images of things like clouds, pastures and underwater scenes. This is aimed at helping passengers feel more comfortable while traveling through a tube without windows.

Sakurajima is an active volcano in Kyushu, Japan, which was formerly an island. In 1914, an eruption connected the island with the Osumi Peninsula. The volcano has been erupting almost continually since 1955. This satellite image taken on August 18, 2013 captured an eruption that spewed ash 20,000 feet above nearby Kagoshima Bay.

This week is the U.S. Open, the second "major" golf tournament of the year. Unlike in years past, this year's U.S. Open will not feature thick rough and narrow fairways. Instead, it will be played on a links-style course just outside of Seattle. The course is called Chambers Bay, and it is going to drive the professionals crazy. The greens have wild undulations. The fairways have fescue grass, which is more coarse than the grass on traditional courses. Chambers Bay is a links-style public course that was built in 2007 by Robert Trent Jones II. It was built on a former gravel mine. It's a seriously gorgeous golf course with jaw dropping views of the Puget Sound.

There are castles throughout all three of Switzerland's regions, and they're all breathtaking. Visiting them is like being transported to a different time period. Many of them are surrounded by scenic views such as the Chillon Castle in Veytaux, a small town in Switzerland's French region. The castle offers spectacular views of all of Lake Genveva. Besides Chillon, there are the Castles of Bellinzona in the Italian region, the Munot Fortress in Schaffhausen and the Hohenklingen Castle in Stein am Rhein, both in the German region, to name a few.

The way in which you mentally organize your time can have a huge effect on your productivity. A study published the Journal of Consumer Research has revealed that people have a tendency to procrastinate not because they are lazy, but because they categorize time illogically. People tend to manage their time in a routine fashion, such as arranging activities by the day, planning expenses by the month and setting goals for the year. Students categorize events based on semesters, farmers by harvesting seasons and accountants by financial quarters. The problem is that this influences when we initiate tasks and can cause procrastination.

Piled scraps of machinery were simply abandoned in the room pictured. The Soviet government were initially considering some of their top space scientists to head the Buran program, but in the end command fell to Col. General Alexander Maksimov, who ran the military space and missile programs.Russia launched their Buran program in 1974 in response to NASA's space shuttle program. One of the main goals of the program was to send the first woman in history on a spacewalk. They actually succeeded four years before even launching their Buran shuttle. In 1984, Svetlana Yevgenyevna Savitskaya became the first woman to complete a spacewalk and the second woman ever in space.

Here's a look at the inside of one of the cockpits, designed for pilots who never flew it. Igor Volk, who today is a retired cosmonaut, was supposed to be commander of the first manned Buran flight. There's a portal connecting the cockpit to the back of the shuttle, which is pitch black inside because the only windows are in the cockpit.

In 1974, Russia launched its largest, most expensive project in space exploration history. The stars of the project, called the Buran program, were its space shuttles, which were built in secret from designs the Soviet secret police stole from NASA. The Soviets invested anywhere from tens of millions to billions on the project, which was terminated in 1993. The Russians built only few prototypes of these shuttles, and only one of them actually flew. The shuttles were designed to carry cosmonauts into space but never did. The first and only flight was unmanned. It took place in 1988 and lasted a total of 206 minutes, during which time the spacecraft successfully launched, orbited Earth twice, and landed. The Daigoji temple in Kyoto, a temple of the Shingon sect of Japanese Buddhism, is a designated world heritage site and a favorite destination to visit in the autumn when the leaves offer an array of vibrant colors.
The Karachi Fuju Garden in Kitakyushu is home to 150 Wisteria plants from over 20 different species. You can walk through its stunning tunnel filled with the flowers.

If you have the chance, visit Japan in the springtime to witness streets filled with cherry blossoms, which are flowers of any of various trees of genus Prunus, especially the Japanese Cherry, Prunus serrulata, which is proclaimed Sakura after the Japanese.

According to its creators, The Toy Box Tiny Home was built to express four things: peace, simplicity, happiness, and recreation. The home is sold with cube-style seating in the main living space. The cubes can also morph into a coffee-table, or be used as storage. A kitchen table for two is perched next to a window for a view and some fresh air.

The Toy Box Tiny Home isn't your typical tiny home.The $48,000 box makes no bones about its 140-square-foot living space. In fact, it flaunts it right up front with its skinny trailer base and whimsical colorblock panels. Though color-block panels dominate most of the home's exterior, the black-rimmed windows add to its design. The home is packed with eco-friendly features, including white plastic roofing.The many windows serve two purposes: natural light and ventilation.

Business Insider is hosting its first ever Instagram photo contest. We are looking for incredible pictures of spectacular views around the world. Whether it's a shot from the top of the Eiffel Tower, a picture from the summit of Table Mountain in South Africa, or a view from your personal balcony, we want to see your best photos. To enter, just follow us here on Instagram, upload a picture showing an incredible view, and use the hashtag #BIbestviews in the caption. Inside the new most expensive listing in NYC you'll find a whopping 23 fireplaces ‚Äî some with original mantels ‚Äî grand staircases, hand-carved wood paneling, an elevator, and, in two of the homes, skylights on the fifth floor. Combined, there are 11 terraces, two of which are double-tiered and located on the rooftop. Breen & Nason Architects built the townhouses in 1879, but they were restored just recently, in 2001, by Joseph Pell Lombardi Architects. The current resident also owns the $35 million brownstone that's for sale next door. While it can't be combined with the triplets, the 9,520-square-foot space would serve as a perfect guesthouse.

The Upper East Side is now home to New York City's new most expensive listing: three identical limestone townhouses on East 62nd Street between Fifth and Madison, available for the package price of $120 million. Sabrina Saltiel and Raphael De Niro (son of actor Robert De Niro), of Douglas Elliman Real Estate, hold the listing for the six-story triplets that extend 73 feet along 62nd Street. Since all three units share a cornice line, they've been combined to create the ultimate UES mansion. But, as the listing notes, the 30,000-square-foot property could easily be transformed into an embassy, club, or retail space.

A hippopotamus walks across a flooded street in Tbilisi, the capital of Georgia, where according to the New York Times there was a state of chaos this weekend after a massive rainstorm ravaged the city and set loose dozens of dangerous animals from a local zoo. Twenty wolves, eight lions, several tigers and jaguars, and the hippopotamus (seen pictured) escaped from the premises and had to be tracked down by local police and zoo staff.

"Jurassic World" had a huge opening weekend at the box office, and it only continues to get bigger. The film, which debuted to an estimated $204.6 million in North America, opened to $307.2 million overseas, bringing its worldwide opening weekend to $511.8 million. That figure not only makes it Universal's largest box-office opening ever, but also the largest worldwide opening for a movie ever and the only to crack $500 million in its first weekend. The 'Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows Part 2' is second all-time at $483 million. - Illustration by @bi_graphics

Jack Horner ‚Äî the paleontologist who's served as technical advisor on all of the Jurassic Park films ‚Äî thinks that he can make a real dinosaur in the next five to 10 years. Horner's idea for a dinosaur, however, is a slightly altered chicken he calls a "dino-chicken.‚Äù We here at Business Insider were hoping for something more frightening to get in the spirit of the latest film, "Jurassic World." When it was first released during the summer of 1993, "Jurassic Park" not only captured the imaginations of viewers with its dazzling special effects, it also made dinosaurs cool again, and made the public interested in paleontology. "It had a big influence on me in wanting to study Paleontology." Dr. John Hutchinson, an evolutionary biomechanist and professor at the Royal Veterinary College in London, explained to Business Insider. "The original film was a landmark in cinema, in many ways and also an important moment in Paleontology that influenced a lot of people including me." - Illustration by @bi_graphics

People are waiting in long lines at @sweetgreen to buy salad. According to Sweetgreen cofounder Jonathan Neman: "Healthy is the new luxury; it's the new cool." Capitalizing on this trend by offering locally sourced, fresh, and affordable ingredients, this salad chain is sweeping the nation.

Iceland likes to do things a little differently, so it's no surprise that rather than giving visitors the chance to walk on a glacier, it allows a select few to head inside one. The luminous ice caves of the Vatnajokull Glacier dazzle small groups led by experts each winter.

Stretching nearly 14 miles, the Aletsch Glacier is the largest in the Alps. The UNESCO World Heritage site is actually made up of three smaller glaciers and creeps slowly downhill at a rate of about 20 inches a day.

Standing like guardians on a mountain, the 202 naturally occurring rock towers of Davolja Varos were formed by a combination of volcanic activity and serious erosion. The resulting hoodoos (also sometimes called tent rocks or fairy chimneys) are regarded as one of Europe's more unusual natural wonders.

You're not just going to stumble upon Fingal's Cave, but effort is the price of admission to this incredible natural wonder. 
The sea cave on an uninhabited island in the Inner Hebrides is made up of massive basalt columns, giving it a magnificent sense of natural architecture.

The highest dune in Europe stands proudly along the Atlantic seashore in the southwest of France. The Dune of Pilat is 1.7-miles long, about 2,000-feet wide, and in places nearly 400-feet tall. It's also migratory: Each year, it moves up to 16 feet inland. But at least for now, the dune still offers a great view of the water.

The thrill of the vertical drop is palpable at Preikestolen, or "Pulpit Rock," a narrow plateau towering nearly 2,000 feet above a fjord in the south of Norway. More than 200,000 visitors every year make the two-hour hike to feel the adrenaline and admire the views.
